Award.AwardTitle: Charge Transfer/Transport in Molecular Systems: Three Challenging Problems
Award.AbstractNarration:
Mark Ratner of Northwestern University is supported by an award from the Chemical Theory, Models and Computational Methods program to carry out research on the development of theoretical methods for the study of electron transfer (ET) in molecular systems. There are three major thrusts for the work: 1). Investigation of ET in hybrid materials constructed of polymers with redox-available sites suspended within them, or with semiconductor or metal quantum dots. The central challenge is relating the dynamics of the polymeric host with the overall transport. 2). Extension of the scheme for describing local inter-atomic contributions to the overall electron currents within the molecule to deal with inelastic behavior, with polaron formation, with vibrational and photonic effects, and with decoherence in general. 3). Development of analytic forms for self-energies for tight-binding metals in 1, 2 and 3 dimensions. The PI and his coworkers try to understand how differing geometries of molecules between electrodes result in different conduction patterns. For example, does current always go through a single molecule, or does it pass between molecules before exiting at the anode?

The work has broad impact on our understanding of a number of situations involving electron transfer (ET) including photochemical and electronic systems. Given the dominant significance of ET, applications to devices for solar energy capture and storage and to environmental stability will follow directly from this work. Ratner is involved in a number of outreach and educational activities, including codirecting the Initiative for Sustainability and Energy at Northwestern (http://www.isen.northwestern.edu/). He is also planning new approaches both to teaching first-year chemistry courses and to giving community outreach talks, based on the importance and interest of energy within the society.

Project Outcomes Report for the General Public
NSF Project Title: Charge Transfer/Transport in Molecular Systems
Principal Investigator: Mark Ratner
Awardee: Northwestern University
Award #: 1058896

  1. This project was entitled Fundamental Issues in Electron Transport. It is a theoretical effort (meaning that concepts were turned into equations, and tested using computational methodologies, as well as comparisons with experiments and suggestions for new experiments). 

Electron transfer is a critical process in nature, appearing in such places as rust, lights, growth, molecular modification, central nervous system functioning, upticks, and hearing.

The role of electron transfer – that is, the motion of an electron from one molecule to another – has been described beautifully by a model due to Marcus that was developed in the 1950s. But these involve macroscopic measurements on large sets of molecules. The fundamental behavior should be found using one molecule which is positioned between a cathode and an anode (meaning that there’s enough potential energy to drive electrons through the molecule from one end to another). Surprisingly, it is a very different set of concepts that are needed for the fundamentals of electron transport in single molecules. Our papers address the details of transport, and its relationship to electron transfer. The applications come as devices in electronics, and in electrochemistry. The grant has been used to train a number of excellent graduate students including Shane Parker (now a postdoctoral fellow at University of California at Irvine), Matt Reuter now an Assistant Professor at Stoneybrook in New York, Dan Gardner who is working for a development firm in Washington, Chris George who is employed at Intel, Brad Veldkamp who works at Dow Chemical, Matt Smeu, faculty member at Binghamton College, Zhilai Li, Assistant Professor at Ball State University in Indiana, Ignacio Franco, Associate Professor at the University of Rochester, and Nick Jackson, completing his PhD at Northwestern.

Finally, the knowledge is of the electron transfer process, which was the fundamental element in the proposal. We tried to develop an idea of the pathways that an electron would take upon going from one electrode through a molecule to another electrode. This is a difficult process, because the electrons are interacting with other electrons, as well as with the vibrational motions of the molecule and the motion at the bridge between the molecule and the electrodes. Because one measurement might be quite different from another measurement because of the geometry change, it is necessary to make many measurements at different geometries, and then average them or display them as a composite.

This is exactly what we’ve done theoretically. We have used advanced time dependent Green’s functions (the best methodology for trying to study electron transport), and we’ve done that at many possible geometries. Averaging over those geometries can provide direct comparisons with experimental measurements.

The motion of electrons through matter is, as pointed out above, fundamental. The knowledge gained from the calculations and the models that we have developed will be of great value in trying to design devices ranging from solar capture to provide energy to neural messaging to protective coatings for buildings and roads.
